ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Multivariable calculus skills: vector-valued functions, partial derivatives, double/triple integrals, Green's theorem, etc. as well as exposure to partial differential equations techniques like separation of variables. How to read a paper with mathematical models in biology.

I gained a broad overview of the math 120 curriculum (functions of multiple variables, parametrization, differentiation, double and triple integrals, line integrals, vector surface integrals, etc.) plus a brief introduction to differential equations. In addition to this, we read a few publications and discussed the mathematical models in detail. Be aware that this course does not teach the whole 120 curriculumalthough it does briefly cover all concepts, we do not practice parametrization, divergence and curl, theorems of stokes and gauss, or any proofs of any such concepts/theorems.
Mathematical modeling, applications from calculus to science, problem solving skills
Basics of multivariable calculus and diffusion-advection models
I learned multivariable calculus up to Greens Theorem, as well as many biological applications to multivariable calculus such as differential equations.
Multi variable calculus, differential equations, reading research papers
I deepened my math abilities and learned about mathematical modeling
I learned about studying multivariable math.
Multivariable calculus and understanding how to model biological phenomenons using differential equations
I feel like a learned a solid basis for multivariable calculus and gained an introduction to how advanced calculus relates back to biology.
How to study for a college math exam and how to use my resources to succeed in a math course (using peers and tutors as a proper resource).

I developed a greater understanding of topics in multivariable differential and integral calculus, with a concerted focus in vector calculus, the parametric and polar coordinate systems, and functions of three and four variables. I also learned the mathematical basis behind various real-world physical processes that have particular application to the biosciences, such as diffusion, advection, and chemotaxis. Overall, I developed a greater intuition for multidimensional space, both spatially and mathematically.

I gained a good general understanding of the tools of multivariable calculus and became more comfortable applying calculus concepts to models in biological research. Biology was not as emphasized as I expected (only one out of our three exams included biological applications), but for me, that wasnt really a problem since I was also interested in just the math portion of the course.
I gained an understanding of fundamental multivariable calculus concepts and how they can be applied to the biological sciences.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was extremely hand-wavey when it came to differential equations. I would have appreciated more time spent teaching the theory and less time repeating "intuition" for mathematical models which were theoretically almost identical.

Strengths: good professor, ample practice, fair tests and grading policies
Weaknesses: may not fully cover 120 material

Strengths: enjoyed the incorporation of engaging papers; good support during office hours/peer tutor hours
Weaknesses: content covered in class was poorly explained and represented only a fraction of what was needed for psets/exam--was forced to self-learn most of the material via lectures from other universities; grading was quite harsh and unforgiving, making for a stressful and unpleasant experience; course title is misleading--only one mathematical model in a biological context was covered (advection-diffusion), and the course felt far closer to a generic math class than an exploration of "mathematical modeling in the biosciences".
Strengths were definitely Professor Halls dedication to his students and the engagement within the course, as it was a small class. There werent many weaknesses besides the early class time.
I learned about resilience and consistency and trying my best.
Very supportive environment designed to facilitate learning. Although, some of the material required students to self learn.

I like that this class didn't cover as much multivariable material as Math 120 would. However, after taking Math 116 which had a high focus on the biology aspect, I was disappointed that Math 121 didn't focus as much on biological applications. But this could just be due to the nature of the material covered and how it generally applies more to physics than biology. Overall, I enjoy John's teaching style, and I feel like I got a lot of personalized feedback in terms of what I'm confused about. I never felt like I couldn't ask a question in class, and the environment in the classroom was one that encouraged collaboration and genuine interest.

strengths: very interested professor and small seminary environment
weakness: no curve and lots of emphasis on testing

Overall, I found the course to be well-organized. However, the parts/units of the class (differential calculus, Fick's Law and it's applications, integral calculus) felt a little disjointed to me, and it might be worth considering switching around the distinct parts of the course to increase the cohesion between the three parts. I also found it a little weird that the middle part of the class wasn't tested at all on the final exam, but I assume there was a specific reason for this exclusion. 
Otherwise, the course had very strong support systems (accessible office hours, practice exams before every exam, review session for midterms and the final exam) that gave many opportunities for practice. There are not many opportunities for improvement.

The course was very organized and the format of class which started with practice problems reviewing old material or previewing new material before we started new content was very helpful. Including many example problems during class was very helpful as it helped prepare us for exams, and the review sessions and practice exams aligned very well to what we were tested on. The course didnt always go in depth enough to get a strong conceptual understanding of the theorems/equations/etc. we were using, and some problem sets were very computational rather than conceptual, but Professor Hall did offer more in-depth explanation in office hours, so it really just depends on the student to choose how much they want to get out of the class. Some of the problems sets were quite challenging and they can be very time-consuming, but if you start early enough to go to office hours or peer-tutor office hours, theyre definitely manageable and partial credit awarded for your work is very fairly graded.

StrengthsDr. Hall's teaching. He is so organized and supportive if you need some help understanding a topic. 
WeaknessesSometimes it was a little unclear how the multivariable calculus and mathematical modeling topics were related.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! John Hall is great and it's a fun way to learn multi if you're into biology.

As someone who entered the course being interested in the math itself, and bearing no contempt for calculus, I would not recommend it to another student. The mathematical models and publications themselves were somewhat interesting, but too similar to each other to feel satisfying to learn past the first one. However, it is a great choice for someone who wants an overview of calc III without the workload of math 120, or who needs to take a calculus class for some other reason (pre-med, etc.) and is averse to math 120.
Yes, it was a very good course that exposes you to different ways of thinking and teaches you the fundamentals of multivariable calculus
Yes for sure!
Do not take this course unless you absolutely need multivariable calculus and want to avoid MATH 120
For sure!! Professor Hall is an excellent professor and you learn a lot of calculus in this class, and its an excellent challenge.
Yes, John Hall is an excellent teacher and the material is interesting and challenging
Yes, it is interesting how biology is integrated

It is a challenging class and you should definitely have a strong background in calc 1 and 2. This is not the class to be reviewing concepts from calc 2 while learning new material. You should definitely be coming in very strong but if this is true for you I think it is a great class and you get out what you put  in. Professor is very nice and kind. But yes it is very quick and intense and you learn a lot about math but also how it applies to other fields, specifically biology and chemistry. Very eye opening and exciting at lest I thought so but yes also challenging.
Absolutely. Professor Hall is an excellent professor who structures this course around seeing his students truly understand the concepts he teaches.
Yes, great course to learn the life sciences applications as well as gain an understanding of multivariable calculus.

Yes! If you're someone that doesn't feel like they need much math for their future or doesn't want to take many math courses, I would recommend this class since it is a nice bridge between multivariable and biology. Since it doesn't cover as much material as Math 120, the class is less of a stressor.
If you're interested in math, I'd suggest this. It is very calculus-focused. We spent around 4 weeks discussing actual biological-related topics.

I would! I think Professor Hall is an excellent professor. He is great at explaining concepts the first time and I was always really impressed that he responded to questions about content with a different explanation instead of repeating a previous explanation that had left you a little lost. He was also great at finding the point of your confusion even when you yourself struggle to identify it. I really appreciated reading the papers as a way to understand the applications of the math we were learning. It made the topics "stick" better in my mind. Overall highly recommend!

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student who wants to learn the mathematical bases behind various biological and ecological phenomena. The discussion of Fick's Law in this course is very relevant and adjacent to a number of topics discussed throughout the introductory biology sequence taught at Yale. Additionally, I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in developing mathematical models within the context of the biosciences. Overall, I would recommend this course to any student who wants to gain a deeper understanding and intuition of multidimensional space and multivariable functions.

I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in biology but isnt planning on studying pure math. I dont know if 120 goes into more depth with proofs and nuances of what we learn, but I assume it might and that would probably be better for someone who is more interested in math than biology. As an MCDB major who wanted a basic understanding of multivariable calculus so I would have the background to go further with math if I want to, it was definitely a good choice and I would choose it again.
Yes! It was well-taught and there was lots of support to help master difficult content.

extras.title: MATH 121 01 - Math Models in Biosciences II
